V6LLfeeItQU-2VG87isHOg.text: Very good ceviches, and the sea bass was exceptional. They also put together a custom tasting menu to cater to our limited time availability.

AYDTzZOkq7BniAIa_etKxw.text: The food was good but that was all about it... We were sat at the tables next to bar... On a busy Friday evening, so many people just standing in front of our table , waiters carrying plates and trays over our head... Not the experience I was hoping to have.. We did not feel comfortable or had a proper chance to enjoy our meal... They should not have bookings for those tables, not suitable for dining... We let them know about the situation as well. The response was pretty much ' it is what it is, nothing we can do' ...

Yd-K5IZhciST2ntnhOFzEg.text: This restaurant is  people/cattle factory. They try to make you order as much as possible and try get you out the doors as fast as possible. They kept rushing us from the moment we got there until the end of the meal. We left very disappointed with the experience. Food is good but very expensive and given the treatment we received will not return.

IWL19wmPFceO_H2yn-3YPA.text: I don't know about this place. Being at Mayfair that kind of tells you this place is not cheap. I don't mind paying for good food, but I didn't find the food to be that great. To start, of course, I have to order ceviche since this is a Peruvian restaurant, and I am biased toward simple fish ceviche. I let the waiter talk me into ordering Corvina with truffles. It sounded like a great idea, but the taste said otherwise. The taste of truffle was too overwhelming and I couldn't taste the freshness of the fish, not to mention there were that many pieces for me to really taste it. My friend and I also shared a few other small dishes, including a crab salad, which was the only thing that was memorable. Chilean seabass is my favorite fish and I usually stop reading any further when I see it on the menu. The waiter raved about the Chilean Seabass lime rice, and I listened to him, yet again. Well, this time the result was a bit better. The dish was good, but certainly not 32 pound good. I thought the rice was on the raw side. I have to say I have had much better Peruvian food for much less.

uPVUhG_twpC9xKnRues0Cw.text: We were food poisoned!! zero stars would be more appropriate .... oh and the restaurant took NO responsibility...not to mention it was a 600 GBP bill, DO not go here!!

rvez18qne3samjE6IIyXHA.text: Loved it! everything is good, the cocktails, the atmosphere, the food...maybe the price I paid was a bit too high, but we let the waitress design our own menu and it comes with a price!Try the spicy beef, amazing...also the seabass was very good and a carpaccio with truffle oil...desserts also are delicious, I had the chocolate fondue and was amazing.need to come more often, it is also 2 minutes to my place, really a shame I didn't discover it earlier.

CuBpydad0yXIQm6ZzWu-AA.text: Amazing. All the ceviches were awesome. The mojitos were awesome. The scene was pretty good. Better than Nobu and much better than Zuma (granted they are different cuisines but same category in terms of sceney, expensive London restaurants).

ZSfoyb1-GetJWWK5SdD-vw.text: One of the best meals we found during a weeklong foodie extravaganza through the Mayfair neighborhood of London. Peruvian style is quickly becoming elevated to cult-status and for good reason. The ceviches are truly mouth-watering palate starters serving to rev up an appetite for the wide selection of exciting shared dishes to come. We enjoyed everything from quinoa to BBQ ribs with each plate better than the last. Definitely recommend this restaurant as a must!

nFhSuyJW4AwW_YmV2kxw7Q.text: I can't rave about this place enough. The food is excellent, the decor is unique and funky in very calculatedly elegant way and the patrons are gorgeous. Everything from the layout, the bar, the lighting, to the music is spot on. Well done by the Zuma/La Petite Maison group.Book in advance as it fills up months in advance. And don't be conned into the Members only bar for 600 quid annually, you can get in even without the precious little card - and it's not worth it.One of my new London faves.

6enmqgGbJIBiOtn9pI8T8g.text: Looking back I really enjoyed our meal and the evening.  There were some dishes (tuna ceviche, duck, spicy beef) that I had that were absolutely fantastic.  Others also thought the scallops were equally great -I didn't have that.  Interesting wine list if a bit pricey in areas.  It's a big expensive night out but I'll go again.

UHohtsQn48pVSRIaHMnuGg.text: One of my best meals and THE best in London. I admire the chef's way of dealing with food. It's like a mix of western food with eastern food and amazingly tasty.We ordered the brunch set and it is way beyond expectation. Especially the main course and dessert afterwards.  Service is also good with the waitress's lovely French accent.

devAMf9cOi6hpVSac1wcIA.text: First time Peruvian food and I love raw fish. For those who loves sushi and love zesty things then this is the best combo for you. The grills are amazing. Definitely will come back here!!

qaFfLDKB2lxmVPtGPdxHRA.text: Combination of fushion and peruvian food. I have taken all the sorts of cheviche and i loved them all.

jVvQuRVv09drPSjyJ-WOFQ.text: Beautiful food,  fantastic service and tasty cocktails. We ate in the bar which had a buzzing atmosphere, so I world recommend here over the slightly more laid back restaurant. You pay a premium but worth every penny.

Ih81KyPfo_crDr4ajUNOUA.text: Went to the gorgeous Peruvian restaurant on Piccadilly for dinner. Tried the expected ceviche - Yellowfin Tuna and Salmon Nikkei, which weren't the best. Followed that up with skewered Pollo (chicken), which was almost like an Indian kebab served with Amarillo (chillies). But the dish that I'd highly recommend is Arroz Nikkei, which is a Chilean Sea Bass served with rice, lime, and chilli; almost like a spicier risotto - par excellence.

t1yS6JKprGO70K6uBOYZQw.text: Poor service, "meh" to good food. I was so excited to dine at Coya as part of a special catch-up with a dear friend I have not seen in two years. We arrived prior to opening 5:40pm on a Sunday. We had a couple of cocktails (my Manhattan sucked, high alcohol-low flavor; don't trust that the bartender knows what he is doing) and sat down shortly after 6pm. They presented the menus, including the £80 per person tasting menu- which we opted for. We were having such a great time (as old friends do) when, just prior to the dessert course, one of the Coya employees comes by to tell us of their policy on how much time one can take up for a table. A policy we were not told of previously. Mind you, this is while there are at least two two-person tables within eyesight that are completely empty, as well as several other larger tables that are completely empty. (It is a cavernous space with LOTS of tables). He interrupts us at least two more times but does not even bring the check (which, if they were in such a rush you would think they would bring by...). This guy finally comes around and wants us to move to the bar- and still has not brought the check! So, horrid service for overpriced food....that I have had far tastier versions of at less than half the cost of Coya at smaller Peruvian mom-and-pop restaurants whose level of service is an infinite improvement upon Coya. Don't bother with this place.

KBzJQ_15b2_DBscpOjvk5g.text: Well Arjun Waney has done it again.The man behind The Art's club, Aurelia, Zuma and Roca has opened a new Peruvian restaurant in Mayfair. My friend and i love his other restaurants and we weren't disappointed. The place looks absolutely stunning. It has a Zuma-esque feel to it but the Peruvian menu, designed by Head chef Sanjay, one is transported right to Peru. If thats not enough, the full Pisco bar will certainly do the trick.The staff is attentive and everything looks amazing, i have to say. I also know there is a small members club upstairs, but i had the chance to have a sneak peak and it is breath taking. I would highly recommend Coya for large parties as well as a romantic dinner. I was even more excited when I heard it is also open for lunch.Go, treat yourself. I know i will be going back there very soon

bZ7KV5hmk06Q7tg0xeoMtg.text: Bottom line: one of the best meals I've ever had. FLAVOR FLAVOR FLAVOR! Every dish was bursting with the most amazing and varied flavor. And it wasn't heavy at all. I highly recommend the yellow fin tuna. Papas bravas were also good. Load up on the small sharing dishes and then order just one main. It's expensive, but well worth it.

is5flFgC-P6MoFYkoJ3law.text: So good!!!!!  I can't wait to go back when I am next in London.  We had a bunch of dishes to share, and they were all fabulous.  My favorite was the chicken 'entree' and the aged beef was very good too.  The ceviche was amazing too.  You must go!

pexxX8FMiNYl_0S9Tq5PPA.text: Tapas style Peruvian food in London, interesting...I heard this place is relatively new and it was fast becoming a favourite happy hour spot with the business crowd around St James'. I actually came here twice during my short stay as two different groups of friends just happened to pick the same spot, it was definitely a much more happening spot on Friday night than it was on a Sunday.The dishes were meant to be shared but the portions are pretty tiny. The ceviche was fantastic, we tried both the lubina and the atun chifa and kept wavering between which one was better! The sea bass was done perfectly, and the spicy beef fillet stood out from the rest of the dishes. The best part is definitely the dessert, I had the chance to sample pretty much the entire dessert menu and was not disappointed with any! I do recommend the chocolate cake and the popcorn one!Oh and one last note, their pisco sours are pretty divine!The only thing is, the price is PRETTY STEEP! As I already said, portions are tiny so come here with a corporate card if you want to be fed properly!

W_yC_KpPJvHjhAIsQhIM_Q.text: Coya delivers what you expect from it: a meticulously designed interior, friendly and attentive staff, very tasty food, beautiful people and a lively atmosphere. It has an attached bar so small groups or romantic dates can lengthen the dinner by drinking some excellent Pisco Sours before or after. The dishes are small but yummy, especially the raw fish-based Tiraditos and Ceviches (although the white corn in my ceviche was not as "poppy" as it should have been). The meat dishes were also very good, I can recommend the chicken, lamb chops and the spicy beef. The pork chops were a little bland. It is definitely a great night out and it is nice to see a "trendy" restaurant that is not Asian.They have three sittings of two hours each, but we were not asked to leave and ended up staying for over three hours at the table. Maybe we got lucky. In any case, two hours is enough as the dishes come quickly.I do wonder if the whole "sharing" concept works as well for this food as it does for Asian food. Chop stick are great for picking food off various plates, but using forks to do so felt like lunch at school.  I thought it was awkward, I would prefer to have had at least the main course being a "proper" individual meal. It all felt a little too much like "tapas" for me and it reveals that the "sharing" concept is just an excuse for not having to organise the kitchen. But the jury is still out. I will certainly go back often.

4-eJMq8M1G6fYpHgB5cung.text: Coya is the place to be..... Busy, vibrant, excellent service, food is absolutely delicious. Desserts also don't disappoint. Wine list is very good and cocktails are worth ordering for sure. There is nothing I don't like about this place. The only improvement would be the portion size for the price. Quality of each dish is excellent, however its a pricey place. Other than that, I looooveeee it.... Will be popping in soon again.

b5hcDr8XYea1gYo3raEzcA.text: The ambient and food are both excellent. We liked the main courses more than the appetisers. In particular, the grilled Chilean Sea bass was delicious.

2IFGrC4syhREJ3bXW9SqCw.text: Me and my partner ate at Coya in mid December. At first we couldn't find the place, it was slightly hidden along the road near Hyde Park, but this kind of led to the cool atmosphere of the place! We went in, there is a trendy bar, and on the other side a trendy restaurant area, buzzing with people, all seemingly a very in-crowd, and all seemingly savouring over Arjan Waney's cuisine! We had some delicious Pisco Sour's, some amazing Peruvian cuisine, and a delicous bottle of wine recommended by a very knowledgable Sommelier. The staff all very friendly and attentive. The walkways in the restaurant were ever so slightly tight, however this was part of the ambience I feel and fit the mood of the restaurant, so not too much of a concern. The prices were also fine for this grade of restaurant and its reputation, which I definitely think it lived up to. I would come back soon for certain!

PRavOdx9At9lgdgt_84jKw.text: We tried around 10 different kinds of tapas for two, and the food was absolutely great. The whole design concept-tableware, furniture, lighting and wall deco-was interesting given that it was supposed to be a Peruvian Tapas bar/restaurant, but the service and the sitting plan were a bit off.

HBS8YrbL9lh2B0JguVVcoQ.text: Amazing place. Service was amazing. I judge places by how long a dirty dish says in front of me. At this place, tonight, no longer than 30 seconds. Can't believe we got a seat at the Ceviche bar. We happened on the White party of the year. Unfortunately we only had Black (it's London)

photos.caption: Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. Ceviche Bar hard at work

IolTcI6uvgZFAgO7Pfy1Ow.text: Had higher hopes. The serivce was average, food took longer than it should have taken to arrive and the emply dishes and dirty plates would build up as nobody wanted to take them away. The serves loved to pour the wine at such a rate that by the time the main came, the bottle was finished - for two people drinks at the bar and one bottle of wine should be enough. When food did arrive, the servers would whisper what the dish was so we had to ask again. The food was ok, nothing amazing, very small portions. Won't be returning anytime soon.

T_2pXu-WTFhOPrdesiyWdg.text: I'm sure this is a lovely restaurant but given how hard it was to book for a Friday evening and how unhelpful the staff were I am not sure what the dining experience would be like.

pyHrsC9kp6YK_2K911V6TA.text: We loved absolutely everything about this restaurant, which was recommended to us by our local foodie friend. We were in town only for six days, so I planned our dinners very carefully. Made reservations knowing very little about Peruvian food. I am not sure I know now to distinguish a Peruvian dish from a non-Peruvian one, but I can most certainly attest to the fact that the food was delicious, wine list impressive, service was absolutely impeccable (thank you, Kinga!) and the ambiance - perfect. We ordered every vegan course on the menu, and there were quite a few options. What a great recommendation (thank you, Tim!). London definitely makes me hand out one 5-star review after another. Who would have thought! Another must visit.

tlaN0ww0_Xq0zQ1QjzsbEA.text: Coya was quite the surprise given the lack of hype about this place. Having been invited, I wasn't sure what to expect, but was pleasantly surprised. Being a Peruvian restaurant, you have to try the Pisco Sours - and the range is long and excellent, as is the wine list. I confess that I drank quite a bit, so cannot remember a great deal about the meal... except that everything was delicious, the flavours of the ceviche were excellent... and little else. Oh dear - it just means I must make another trip. 4 stars as we were hearded from our table to a rather soulless bar after 2.5 hours.

TgyQZHH1qyyJqwrCG4jo1g.text: Unfortunately, we experienced the worst service in London here. The food was not super amazing but nice. We reserved here on the recommendation of the staff at The Ritz where we are staying. First, the tables are way to close together. I get they want to maximize space/ revenue but the restaurant was not full and we were on top of the other table. Not even a foot in between. This would not have been that huge of a deal if the server (not our server) wasn't friends with the people at the table next to us. She kept sliding in between the tables and putting her bottom inches from my plate and uncomfortably close to my face. I swear she almost sat on our table at one point. Some might find this appetizing, I did not. The first time it was mildly annoying but I waited for her to leave and continued with my meal. After the fourth or fifth time my patience was gone and I asked her to move so I could get out. I did mention this to a man I assumed to be in management and the waitress as they happend to be standing together by me and they apologized in a defensive way saying it had already been addressed. Well if it was addressed how come no one apologized before I mentioned it. Also, really how can a waitress have so little common sense to begin with? Additionally, we ordered drinks with call liquor at a cost as described in the menu. We asked for this liquor to be prepared as a cocktail and we're subsequently charged to make the liquor into cocktail. On the bill it appeared to be rung up like it was an additional drink. They told us the charge was accurate because they made it a cocktail. I have not seen this anywhere else and there was not a notation in the menu that if you want the liquor mixed or as a cocktail it is extra. Is the glass extra because if so perhaps just take the bottle and pour it in my mouth. Really??!!! Honestly, it's not the money. We have a very short time here and just wanted a nice meal/experience and were more than happy to pay for it but spending 200 pounds and being disappointed is just that disappointing. The 23 pound automatic gratuity added was a joke. I presume we could have asked for it to be removed/ adjusted but we were so over being there we paid and left. We wanted a fun evening and we ended up feeling ripped off and disrespected.

oDxTlYrdzt3TzsmKDMxcjQ.text: Absolutely amazing food. Was a real experience. We asked the waiter to choose a selection of food for us and we got to try lots of new things. Felt really well looked after!It was very pricey but I feel like it was worth the experience. Would definitely go back, but not before saving some pennies!

2TJqMbtXMUmqpHMjoHS1zA.text: Ceviches were a hit.  The Chilean sea bass was like butter melting in my mouth.  The desserts were mediocre.  Only big minus was the incredibly loud live music that was playing in the members' area.  It was too loud to have a conversation without shouting at the top of our lungs.

ribPMJBU376E9b0a8gb7wg.text: Buddha Bar for Peruvian cuisine.Peruvian food is all the rage and this uber chic and trendy place at the top of Piccadilly is the place to be seen and scene. Gorgeous decor of rich dark wood and warm accents go with the sexy cocktail list. Coya is definitely aiming for the bar scene here though its infusion Peruvian menu was extensive, and quite good -though not amazing. Ceviches are the strong  suit here as are there small bites. Service was friendly though also not amazing.  It took a while to get the orders in. And if you sit on the back near the open show kitchen you will hear the constant shouting of 'service' from the staff awaiting food pick up.But for atmosphere and menu this place rocks and is a great time. Expensive, yes, but where in Mayfair isn't. The upstairs members only lounge club looks like its worth getting to know someone for a peek in, but if not the bar and restaurant will do just fine for a good time. Worth a shot. And by that I mean a tequila shot...

jDMCqFn7dwzr_I-zzIq45g.text: Great Peruvian food, unique dining experience. The bar is also great, with awesome cocktail selections. Place is open till very late, and is usually packed so make reservations in advance.

Fz9NS0TUjNehabRIegxMsQ.text: Came here with a client expecting a great experience and leaving disappointed. The food was great (we had the chicken skewers, pork belly, spicy beef, and chicken entrees). The service on the other hand is terrible, we had to ask for water six times. Having flown from NY the day before I was dehydrated and not happy at all. Wouldn't come back or recommend to any of my colleagues.

Ybm3UbhaoLvpRbyo6pReqA.text: This place is sexy. Sleek on top, speakeasy on the bottom and the food? Oh si si si! The best Peruvian I've had outside of Lima. They have multiple versions of ceviche, tiradito, all the classic small dishes (e.g. anticuchos, causa), meats, fish, an extensive bar menu and a stunning-looking dessert menu (see: coyarestaurant.com/resta… - um Mousse de Lucuma? Lucuma mousse, passion fruit, yuzu sorbet and sesame seeds... wow.) Oya Coya!

CIEXBfazo8YUSFgymrt8Aw.text: Never have I been to a place that got it so right with the food and so wrong with the service. The food is absolutely amazing. This is the second time we went for the tasting menu which exceeded expectations. However, we went there with some senior family members and the service was unusually rushed. Dishes kept arriving before we were even half way through the previous serving. When we requested our server to slow down, he told us that he was helpless since he could not control the kitchen. We had to actually threaten to walk out before the food service slowed down to a manageable level. We had to repeatedly keep asking for fresh cutlery and serve our own wine since the staff was either inattentive or unavailable. On a positive note, the place is bursting with energy and our Sommelier recommended some great wine. What a pity that there is such lack of attention to detail at such a fancy venue...

IspqP5Slw9z-KjWVjHJhSQ.text: Unfortunately I chose to arrive here late. My bad. Atmosphere great. Service attention while they were trying to get ready to close, poor. Quality of food - excellent to average. Speed of food excellent. Weird thing. I ordered three things: tuna taco, pollo(chicken) taco and chips with shrimps and guacamole. Received: tuna ceviche, veggie tacos, tuna sashimi and an empanadas croquette dish I couldn't identify. Bottom line come early, verify your order twice and you should have a good time! Assuming you're ok with loud Latin music, which I love and is why I came here!

pVwOaAYYaH89fmGbgX0hRQ.text: This is the number one place to eat in London (in my eyes!)The spicy beef is addicting.. you literally cannot get enough! And the sea bass.... I cant say enough!There is something for everyone on the menu! Very pricey but well worth it!

kW2UcRYTMFfGhZZqBWnUwA.text: Excellent service, suprême food. I only give 3 stars because the lady wine captain charged me 6 bottles of wine when I only had 4. Honest mistake ( maybe??) but when she was proven wrong she insisted I had 5 (before she said " you had 6 or perhaps 5 "although she could only  show 4 empty ones :). She never apologized. Thankfully the manager did.

qbsPAeNpqB3k022fefD_KQ.text: The service is brilliant here, we came for a quick pre-theatre meal and only had an hour. We didnt know what was best to order so completely left it up to the waiter and he bought out quick delicious dishes which gave a well-rounded feel to the restaurant.I think the bar is cool and overall there's a good ambience with cool decor.

5fRRZokW0iqQm91fqPpXKA.text: I'm so impressed with this restaurant that I can't waited to go back. There nothing that I can say that I didn't like. The food is super fresh and just amazing the flavors dance in your mouth. You must try the sea bass risotto also try the in house cocktail selection. This is a high-end place and won't disappoint anyone. Keep up the excellent job. Cheers

-mq-balUa-zYB_444VWKLQ.text: We were a group of five and our bill came out to be £54 per person.The good:- I don't have much experience with Peruvian food, but everything we had was fantastic!!- This place is for sharing. i don't remember everything, but between the five of us we had 3 ceviches, 2 tiradito, 1 antichuco, 1 salad, 2 vegetable dishes, 2 mains, 4 pisco sour and 4 coffee/tea- The 3 ceviches we had were excellent, we got Lubina Clasico (sea bass), Atun Chifa (yellow fin tuna), and another one with truffle that I cant seem to find online. My favorite was the truffle one.- for Toradito we had Conchas (scallops) and Atun Nikkei (Yellow fin tuna). I really liked the tuna.- for antichuco we had the tiger prawn, which was unimpressive.- for salad and vegetable, we had corn salad, asparagus and broccoli. I loved the corn salad!- for mains, we had chicken and sea bass. I honestly think we should have just gone for more ceviches and toraditos since I thought they were just alright.- pisco sour was pretty strong and goodThe bad:- We had a reservation at 6pm and it was obvious they were trying to hurry us up throughout the meal so the next table can be seated. In fact, we were actually told that as the waiter hurried us to order. Then different waiters kept coming by and asking if we are done, even though there were still food on our plates!- they try to add hidden charges without asking. We had chips and guacamole while waiting for a friend and they ordered is two servings without asking. Then, if you don't ask them to stop, they will keep refilling your still/sparkling water which are £5 per bottle. These are minor since it adds up to only a few pounds per person, but I never like it when restaurants do this.

photos.caption: Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. Ceviche

Q34gJ__KM3eBn43j72xGsQ.text: Great ambiance, good service, and food was delicious, although coming from NYC, it felt a little overpriced for what it was. Try the ceviches.

Nb7eN7laLNs8qbk3Gca-BA.text: Absolutely fantastic service, food, drinks, staff & music! Highly recommend COYA - especially if you're a member. This place was amazing. Tuna tartare, I could everyday. Thank you!!

zVOiF7HmEleYAYZFs-a9RA.text: The space and the atmosphere were completely amazing. I felt like I was in South America the second we made it down the stairs. The wait staff was very attentive and took care of us well. A DJ was playing near the bar which added to the cool vibe. All of the food was good, but not I was as impressed as I thought that I would've been given the prices for what we ordered. Again, all food was great, but I wasn't blown away. And it was VERY pricey. My husband ordered what was dubbed a "margarita" from the cocktail menu and was not especially happy with what he received as it did not come remotely close to being a margarita. Overall, it was really cool place, but I wouldn't make a point of going back for dinner. For drinks and the atmosphere, possibly.

photos.caption: Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. View of the kitchen from our table
Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. Calamari
Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. Iron pot truffles, potatoes and wild mushrooms

B0Kg4OfMTUghHoFk14am9Q.text: I booked this restaurant for a special birthday occasion  because I had a wonderful experience when I was in town last May.Tonight was the opposite, I was embarrassed! The waitress was snippy, she got annoyed when we didn't order her suggestion (the most expensive ones, of course) or the tasting menu. On several occasions, our plates were taken away as we were eating, they took away halfway drunk cocktails and then wanted us to order and pay for new ones, and the waitstaff kept banging into us.Food was bland and the meat was tough and fatty! I was shocked!!

6FPrswTuvTbWxWWZWenjHg.text: Coya is an outstanding place for a dinner date. I came here with my boyfriend for a special occasion and everything was perfect! The restaurant was chic and lively, with a DJ playing throughout the night at the bar and small dance area towards the front of the restaurant.We started with some Chilean white wine, which was fruity and crisp and was going to pair well with a seafood-heavy menu. The Coya menu featured Peruvian small plates consisting of ceviche, sashimi and grilled items. There are three things that were a must: the Atun Chifa ceviche, Hiramasa sashimi and the Arroz Nikkei iron pot. The Atun Chifa is a yellow fin tuna ceviche prepared in a citrusy dressing with a touch of soy and sesame and some prawn crackers, served atop a bed of shaved ice. This dish was really creative, flavorful and refreshing! I definitely recommend this for an appetizer.The Hiramasa sashimi is a great follow up to the appetizer. This dish featured king fish sashimi served with a truffle and mushroom dressing. It was delicate yet indulgent. I couldn't get enough of the dressing.The Arroz Nikkei is basically a sea bass risotto served in a hot stone pot. I'm not a fan of risotto but this was recommended by a friend and it exceeded my expectations. I've had my fair share of overcooked and dry sea bass but this one was succulent and cooked to perfection. The risotto was creamy but not mushy. All the flavors were really well balanced in this dish and the squeeze of lime helped to enhance all the flavors. I would come again for any of these three dishes.Additionally, my boyfriend and I also shared some wings, crab tacos and a chocolate dessert. The crab tacos were crispy on the outside and creamy on the inside but the wings were nothing mind blowing. The waiter gave us a bowl of lemon water to wash our fingers in afterwards, which was a plus to the service here. The rich chocolate molten cake was really yummy paired with a scoop of tangy passion fruit ice cream. Overall, dinner at Coya was a refreshing and very enjoyable experience! Our waiter was attentive and friendly, and the food and wine were great! I've never experienced Peruvian cuisine prior to this and the food here makes me want to visit Peru. P.S. There's also a free coat check at the front, which is great when you don't want to carry around your winter coat especially if you're planning to hit the dance area.

DtKKfaXUscqjyzrsvzwAdQ.text: This is by far, one of my favorite restaurants in London. I also live in Miami so this restaurant makes me feel as if I'm there and not in London. You don't want to come here on a Sunday unless you want a quiet romantic evening and a bonus you can dine in their private members only area. The best days are Wed, Friday and Saturday. They have a DJ plays Latin lounge music that sets the mood. Every dish and drink I've had was absolutely well made and exciting in taste and visually. Note the whiskey sour drink infused with poA few favorites are the rum drink, the pork ribs and iron sea bass dish.

photos.caption: Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom

V9U_d2ssCHrJKZStJf6x3g.text: This place has a very cool vibe, although it is a little uppity. They have a fairly strict 2 hour rule for dining so be warned. Highly recommend the Chilean sea bass iron pot - one of the best dishes I've ever had. The ribs and tuna ceviche were also delicious

DJYV73sQx5qYTGDfNmlwNQ.text: a good place for dates, dime lights and lounge music. South American style decor.Food is O.K., it's relatively over priced.

photos.caption: Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom
Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom
Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom

kbwGnlBmqOJYe0g-f4t32A.text: Fab fab fab fab place. Went here for a date with my hubby dearest .. we started with crisp glass of Albariño. The fried calamari is brilliant and quite different to the ones you usually get it. The ceviche trio was awesome and refreshing. With food so good, we got greedy and over ordered the prawn tempura.. it was so light and great. For the mains, we had the spicy beef fillet and the tiger prawn. The spicy beef is the best piece of meat I have had till now. It was out of the world. The service is what blew my mind. The staff are brilliant, they are always there to attend to you yet not hanging around you. Very unpretentious place that serves great food and has fab staff. Totally totally recommend this to anyone .. must try this place

photos.caption: Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. Prawn tempura, patatas bravas and tiger prawn (main)

oRdmJPaET81GYkWJVvV37w.text: I came here with a large group of friends to try their sunday brunch menu. I don't think any of us felt particularly welcome, but although the service felt a bit off, the yummy food means they still deserve 4 stars.For the brunch menu, they'll bring starters and dishes to share, so you just need to choose a main dish...then more sharing deserts are presented last. Everything we tried was gorgeous. I loved the cerviche the edamame, the meaty skewers and the calamari. I shared mains with my friend so got to try the roast lamb and the sea bream...both of them were delicious. Other good points:- You can have bottomless champagne for £20. They were very clear that they would not serve the bubbles until we had food...and that when we received deserts, that would be our last top-up. All the rules made it sound like they were going to be stingy with the bubbles...but they were pretty good at keeping our glasses full! - For some reason, just after we finished out mains, there was a magician who came around to show us some card tricks!! Strange things:- The waiters seems just a bit cold and odd. - The menu is a little bizarre. You just have to choose a main dish...and they have options for £36 or £46. And then they have other options for +£10 (so I'm not sure why they don't list them in the £46 menu!?) It is all a bit confusing.

5QzcXNrs-cI-LhIMFX0Wnw.text: This place is supposed to be Peruvian, Latin American, although what if anything is remotely that ? but there wasn't one memorable dish which reminded me even remotely of anything I have eaten in Peru or other Latin American countries. The portions are small and flavours not authentic at all,  the only thing that filled me up, barely  was the dessert, and I don't even  like dessert. After  spending 100 pounds pp with just two drinks each, am struggling to say anything positive. The service was pleasant, saving grace, and the decor and ambience is good.  The place was chosen by a friend who doesn't live here, would never have chosen it myself.

ig59l6j-drYs1qwXGi1VZw.text: Up and coming Peruvian restaurant. Posh and chic.What sets apart is the quality of food at Coya.Strategically positioned on the edge of Piccadily (118), there is a special function room at the parlor level. The bar and restaurant is one level below ground floor. Cloak room is also situated on the lower level.I didn't hangout at the bar but it looks well stocked The food is really nice. Out of the 7-8 things we have ordered and shared, only one was not at par. Ceviches were good - the only complaint is the size of the plate.We ordered sea bass which was fantastic. Beef on a skewer was equally mouth watering.  Must try.Our service, bar few small delays, was pretty good.A must visit

photos.caption: Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom

OqKPN7FSbFRBG68GgYjS9w.text: I would certainly have given 5 stars had the service been better. After being seated half an hour past our reservation we were asked to move to the bar for our desert. Unacceptable. The food, however was outstanding!

haufUD-wMyNjXqkrI9U75A.text: I loveeeed the place it's the type of atmosphere I love . It's big the entrance is very artistic very london hipster chic . The food it's a hit or miss . Some things we looooooved like the potatos the octopus some we hated we had a meat plate we didn't like. I suggest ordering a couple of things and sharing. One of my favorite spots in London still

5_AihwFWSoyr0xj6g-a0tA.text: Visited Coya Mayfair our first night in London and by the time we left, it ranked as the best meal we had during our stay. Food, ambiance and service were outstanding. Having never before dined on Peruvian food and needing some guidance with the menu, our server could not have been more informative and accommodating. He was right on target for the amount of food to order (he even said our 5 dishes shared, should be sufficient and to not over-order!) and the selection was perfectly balanced and matched to our taste. We enjoyed every delicious bite of Yellowfin Tuna Ceviches, Yellowtail Tiraditos, Josper Octopus, Pork Back Ribs and a side of broccoli. Can't rave enough about Coya! Not to be missed when in London.

photos.caption: Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. Pork Back Ribs (Costillas de Cerado)
Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. Josper Grilled Octopus
Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. Yellowfin Tuna Ceviches

dO0yK0RGgIEhEUL0OV23UA.text: I would have given it a higher rating if it weren't for their 2 hour table time limit.  It really is disappointing that the restaurant would rather turn the tables over & over again vs. ensuring customers had a pleasant experience.  We ordered a second bottle of wine and then were told that they could fulfill the order, but that we'd have to move to the bar in 20 minutes. The hostess even made it a point to say that we did arrive 10 minutes late for our reservation.  Really?  Who does that?  Unacceptable. The food, however, was great.

XqCv3t2ZGdZfKIts7Onubw.text: An amazing twist on Peruvian food. We went with small plates and none disappointed with the Shrimp being amazing.

56vpNfiLn64AcVHPSU8VWw.text: Nice Peruvian restaurant. Nice decoration.Nice service. Peruvian food. Very special. Prices are acceptable.

photos.caption: Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom

U9kB2EeF_NiinjWOSwFJ2Q.text: Delicious. 5 star cocktails. Mix of ceviche highly recommended, as well as beef! Desserts could have been better to be honest, they are very average I wouldn't say they are the same quality as the mains and starters. Especially for what you pay.

ns24FSw_EVGUcy0Lo8Q7YA.text: This was in the top three meals I had on my monthlong Europe vacation--and considering one of them was Restaurant Gordon Ramsay, that's saying something. It was pricey, but the food and service was well worth it. Our waiter was a bit eccentric yet extremely enthusiastic about the menu.The Ron Jeremias was one of the best cocktails I've had--sweet and tangy with a generous slice of passionfruit on top.From worst to best raw dishes: lubina clásico, atún chifa, pez limón. That last one (yellowtail tiradito) was a definite highlight.From worst to best warm dishes: arroz nikkei, broccoli, spicy beef, octopus.For dessert, the chocolate fundido and caramel con chocolate were very solid and more than satisfied our sweet tooth.Overall, everything ranged from decent to fantastic. Would love to return next time I'm in London.

photos.caption: Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. Ron Jeremias w/ passionfruit slice
Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate fundido and caramel con chocolate
Photo of COYA - London, United Kingdom. Arroz nikkei, broccoli, spicy beef, octopus

4To99IaVeUygWGnllFZo3Q.text: My husband and I were on completely different pages (not unusual) after dining at Coya last month. Whereas I'd give Coya 3 stars, he'd give it a 4.5. Ultimately (and obviously) I decided to go with 4 stars.Ambiance: We went for dinner and the place filled up around 7pm, right when we arrived. Coya is dark and sleek and a probably not a place for a child (who was with us, as she most always is).Service: Good. The waitress was friendly. The one thing I didn't like was her recommendation to order 2 appetizers, 1 entrée, and one dessert per person. If we'd followed her suggestion we'd have had WAY too much food.Food: There were hits and some misses.-- Pollo Tacos - These are TINY. I mean each is probably 2 bites. I didn't try these but my daughter loved them so much she ordered another. I cringed since they were very overpriced.-- Papa Seca - This was interesting. I couldn't taste the egg and instead just tasted potatoes. I don't think this was a hit for anyone at the table.-- Lobster - This came over rice and was very good. A bit chewy but we all still enjoyed this dish.-- Lubina Chilena - The seabass in this dish was delicious! Perfectly cooked.-- Patatas Bravas - Terrible. Definitely don't recommend this greasy side.-- Asparagus - Nothing special and I don't want to think about how much we paid for 6 stalks of asparagus.Pricing: Most tapas places lean towards the expensive side and Coya is no exception.Overall: Not sure I'd return here but apparently my husband wants to back. I'll let you guess who'll win that battle. :)
